titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Tanja Lorkovic Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Carol King

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 07:13

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of materials relating to the coup d'état in the Soviet Union and the democracy movement in the Baltic States. The material was gathered by Tanja Lorkovic during the International Federation of Library Associations (IFLA) conference in Moscow in 1991 and during trips to Baltic libraries. Also included are correspondence and related materials pertaining to the Slavic and East European Collection at Yale University Library, the Slavic and East European Section (SEES) of the Association of College and Research Libraries (ARL) of which Lorkovic is a past chairperson, as well as subject files of the Russian library assessment projects organized by her and sponsored by the International Research and Exchanges Board (IREX). Correspondence with literary and political figures is included, as well as an interview with Lorkovic.

langmaterial.language: The materials are in English, Russian, and Croatian.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Personnel records (box 2) of Accession 2014-M-037 are restricted as established by Yale Corporation regulations.n.

Original audio, film, and video recordings, as well as preservation masters and duplicating masters may not be played. Readers may only play use copies. If a use copy of a particular recording does not exist, researchers must consult with the reference archivist for policies and procedures regarding the creation of duplicating master and use copies of original recordings.

Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Tanja Lorkovic Papers (MS 1627). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged by accession.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Tatjana Bujas Lorkovic was born on January 17, 1933, in Beograd, Yugoslavia. She emigrated to the United States in 1964. She received an M.A. in Yugoslav Languages and Literatures and Russian Language and Literature from the University of Croatia at Zagreb in 1957; an M.A. in Library Science from the University of Minnesota in 1968; and an M.A. in Russian Language and Literature from the University of Iowa in 1972. Lorkovic worked at the University of Iowa as Slavic librarian (1968-1972) and as head of the cataloging department (1973-1989). From 1989 until her retirement in January 2014, she served as curator of the Slavic and East European Collection at Yale University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of materials relating to the coup d'état in the Soviet Union and the democracy movement in the Baltic States, gathered by Tanja Lorkovic during the International Federation of Library Associations (IFLA) conference in Moscow in 1991 and during trips to Baltic libraries. Also included are correspondence and related materials pertaining to the Slavic and East European Collection at Yale University; the Slavic and East European Section (SEES) of the Association of College and Research Libraries (ARL) of which Lorkovic is a past chairperson, as well as subject files of the Russian library assessment projects organized by her and sponsored by the International Research and Exchanges Board (IREX). Correspondence with literary and political figures is included, as well as an interview with Lorkovic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This initial accession to the papers comprises newspaper issues, posters, magazine articles, clippings and other propaganda materials that were circulating among the protesters in Moscow during the August Putsch of 1991 (August 19-22). In the Putsch, a group of members of the Soviet Union's government deposed Mikhail Gorbachev and attempted, with the help of the army, to take control of the country. The coup leaders were hard-line communists who feared that Gorbachev's "Perestroika" reforms went too far, and that the expected new union treaty among the Soviet Republics gave too much power to the republics and weakened the central government. Although the coup collapsed after three days and Gorbachev returned to power, the August Putsch proved to be the beginning of the end of the Soviet Union.

Lorkovic, in Moscow at the time attending the IFLA (International Federation of Library Associations) conference, was overwhelmed by the events, since the streets of Moscow filled with tanks and everybody was expecting the street fights to start any moment. She took photographs of the street events and collected materials documenting these turbulent and historical days. Some posters were pulled down from the walls at metro stations, some papers purchased from the newspaper stands, and some materials were distributed by protesters with whom Lorkovic mingled in the streets. She was also given photocopied materials by Russian librarian colleagues.

Lorkovic left Moscow on the 25 August 1991 for the Baltic countries, visiting Tallinn, Tartu, Riga, and Vilnius and witnessing the joy and celebration of peoples who had just obtained their independence after many years of subjugation to the Soviet Union.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession comprises materials pertaining to the activities of the Slavic and East European Section (SEES) of the Association of College and Research Libraries (ACRL). The papers were compiled by Tanja Lorković, past chair of the SEES and includes correspondence, meeting minutes, agendas, memoranda, printed material, and writings.

did.unittitle: Correspondence between Tanja Lorkovic and Dubravko Ivancan [Croatian poet]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession comprises materials compiled by Tanja Lorkovic as organizer of the library assessment project funded by the Special Projects in Library and Information Science Program of the International Research and Exchanges Board (IREX). The files contain correpondence, project proposals and summaries, printed material, and photographs pertaining to librarianship in Russia after the fall of Communism. The accession also includes printed material and photographs of Eastern European libraries.

did.unittitle: IREX library and archive assessment projects
Photographs of libraries and librarians, and an article, "Revolution Not Over for Eastern European Libraries," by Lorkovic

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession comprises photographs taken by Tanja Lorkovic on various acquisitions trips, depicting various libraries and staff; conferences; exhibits; and political events and politicians of Eastern Europe.

"The Past as Prologue: Building Yale University Library's Slavic and East European Collection from the Beginning of the Twentieth Century until Today," by Tanja Lorkovic

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes related correspondence with Gaddis Smith, Larned Professor of History emeritus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is both personal and professional. Some letters refer to the Croatian situation in the 1990s.

did.unittitle: Interview of Tanja Lorkovic by Robert J. Donia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The interview with Tanja Lorkovic was conducted on March 29, 2010, by Professor Robert J. Donia, University of Michigan, regarding her uncle Srećko Bujas and his life during World War II and as a judge in Sarajevo, as well as Lorkovic's experiences during the war.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The transcript was prepared by Tanja Lorkovic and contains additional information not present on the audiorecording.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists primarily of correspondence with Croatian literary and political figures. Aspects of Lorkovic's international librarianship are documented in Topical Files and Writings.

langmaterial.language: The majority of the correspondence is in Croatian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lorkovic was instrumental in leading a Yale effort to assist in restoring The Bosnia-Herzegovina National Library destroyed by Serb artillery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lorkovic was selected as one of four library consultants to participate in the Indonesian Education Project at the University of North Sumatra.

Article in Kaliningradskaia Pravda , a Kaliningrad weekly newspaper

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The article features an international seminar attended by Tatjana Lorković, curator of the Slavic and East European Collection at Yale University Library, Michael Neubert, Library of Congress, and archivist Ellen Scaruffi . Topics included the roles of women and the leadership roles held by men in libraries and archives; disparity of pay between men and women, often irregardless of qualifications; the increasing number of men entering the profession, causing a rise in salaries; and the need to recognize the commitment of librarians and archivists to their profession and compensate them accordingly. (page 8)

did.unittitle: 2003 calendar highlighting the 300th anniversary of St. Petersburg

langmaterial.language: Most of the material is in English but some is in various Eastern European languages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The accession comprises primarily correspondence files with individuals, e.g., Yale faculty, domestic and foreign librarians, or on special subjects related to Slavic and Eastern European studies and libraries.
